review.title: Reflective Oracles: A Foundation for Classical Game Theory
review.abstract: Classical game theory treats players as special---a description of a game contains a full, explicit enumeration of all players---even though in the real world, "players" are no more fundamentally special than rocks or clouds. It isn't trivial to find a decision-theoretic foundation for game theory in which an agent's coplayers are a non-distinguished part of the agent's environment. Attempts to model both players and the environment as Turing machines, for example, fail for standard diagonalization reasons.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 8.04 145v 1 [cs.A I] 1 7A ug2 01 In this work we present a kind of "reflective" oracle that is able to answer questions about the results of oracle machines with access to the same oracle. These oracles avoid diagonalization by answering some random questions. We show that machines with access to a reflective oracle can be used to define rational agents using causal decision theory. These agents model their environment as a probabilistic oracle machine that can contain other agents as an undifferentiated part. We show that such agents, when they interact, play a nash equilibrium, with randomization in mixed strategies deriving from randomization in the oracle's answers. This can be seen as a basis for classical game theory in which the players are nothing special.

sections.heading: 5 From Nash Equilibria to Reflective Oracles
sections.text: In the previous section we showed that a reflective oracle can be used to find Nash balances (BR = mixed normal form games). It is interesting to note that we can also go in the other direction: for finite sentences R it is a special case of Theorem 2.1, but it not only provides a more elementary proof, but also provides a constructive way to find such oracles (by using any algorithm to find Nash balances in GR).

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Joyce and Gibbard [12] describe a justification for mixed Nash balances in relation to causal decision theory. Specifically, they discuss a state of self-regulation that extends CDT to cases where one's action is evidence of different fundamental conditions that could change what actions are rational. An action confirms itself if and only if it causally maximizes the expected benefit in a world model based on the evidence that this action is taken. Consider, for example, the setting of a matching pennies game in which players can accurately predict each other. However, the fact that player A plays "heads" and play "tails" in response is evidence that player A would play "tails" and so that the "heads" action "does not ratify itself." However, the mixed strategy of dealing with the coin-ratifying world is "evidence that player A plays" tails "and that player B plays" plays "tails."

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced reflective oracles, a kind of probabilistic oracle that is capable of answering questions about the behavior of oracle machines with access to the same oracle. We have shown that such oracle machines can implement a version of causal decision theory, and have used this to establish a close relationship between reflective oracles and the Nash equilibrium. We have focused on answering questions about oracle machines that persist with probability 1, but the principle of reflection presented in Section 2 can be modified to apply to machines that do not necessarily persist, replacing the condition P (MO () = 1) < p = ⇒ P (O (M, p) = 1 with condition P () (MO () = 6 = 0) < p = ⇒ P (O (M, p) = 0) = 1This is identical to the previous prognostic principle, if MO is reasonably translatable, but if MO is also reasonably probable.

Theoretical models of smarter-than-human intelligence such as Hutter’s universally intelligent agent AIXI [17] typically treat the agent as separate from the environment, communicating only through well-defined input and output channels.

In the real world, agents run on hardware that is part of the environment, and Orseau and Ring [13] have proposed formalisms for studying space-time embedded intelligence running on hardware that is embedded in its environment.

The ability to deal with non-halting machines opens up the possibility of applying reflective oracles to simplicity priors such as Solomonoff induction [18], which defines a probability distribution over infinite bit sequences by, roughly, choosing a random program and running it.

In this paper, we introduce a “reflective” type of oracle, which is able to answer questions about the outputs of oracle machines with access to the same oracle. These agents model their environment as a probabilistic oracle machine, which may contain other agents as a non-distinguished part. We show that if such agents interact, they will play a Nash equilibrium, with the randomization in mixed strategies coming from the randomization in the oracle’s answers.
